key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse was acquitted of all charges in the Kenosha shootings.
The verdict has sparked a debate over guns, vigilantism, and racial injustice in the U.S.
Rittenhouse testified he acted in self-defense during the 2020 protests in Kenosha.
The case has divided public opinion, with some viewing Rittenhouse as a patriot and others as a vigilante.
Rittenhouse was charged with homicide, attempted homicide, and reckless endangering for killing two men and wounding a third.
President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump have both commented on the verdict.
The trial and verdict come amid other high-profile trials reflecting racial divisions in the U.S.
Prosecutors portrayed Rittenhouse as a 'wannabe soldier' while his defense argued he was defending himself.
Witnesses gave conflicting accounts of the events leading to the shootings.
Legal experts suggested the defense may have had an advantage due to Wisconsin's self-defense laws.
spokespersons: The Rev. Jesse Jackson (Civil Rights Leader)
Kenosha County District Attorney Michael Graveley
Mark McCloskey (Republican candidate for U.S. Senate in Missouri)
